awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Biological Adaptation to Stress -- Molecular, Cellular, Ecological
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Pepperdine University, located in Malibu, CA, will support the training of 8 students for 11 weeks during the summers of 2016- 2019. Research opportunities associated with the program range from cellular to organismal systems, and students will have access to state of the art equipment and computer systems essential for such research.  The primary goals of the program include the following: 1) provide training in the application of the scientific method; 2) involve students in collaborative and interdisciplinary research; 3) expose students to the overall enterprise of science as it relates to the design and implementation of a research project; 4) develop skills in scientific communication; 5) provide students with training in ethical decision-making as it relates to science; 6) train students in various forms of scientific communication; and 7) foster an appreciation for career opportunities in the life sciences as well as training in preparation for graduate school.  In collaboration with a faculty mentor, each student will be encouraged to design a research project that interfaces with ongoing research at Pepperdine.  This research will involve a mixture of lab and field-based activities and will culminate with a student symposium that includes both oral presentations and a poster session.  

Over four years of funding, the program will award NSF fellowships to a total of 32 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities and from underrepresented populations. Student recruitment is primarily web-based but includes direct communication with undergraduate-serving institutions with high enrollment of underrepresented groups.  Several factors are considered important for student selection, including academic record, letters of reference, student interest in obtaining an advanced career in science, and diversity. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. 

Program success will be assessed using a common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) as well as specific tools developed within the Pepperdine program.  Follow-through of the REU program will include presentations at regional and national meetings.   For more information about the program, students can visit the website (https://seaver.pepperdine.edu/surb/) where they can apply online.  In addition, students can contact the PI (Dr. Jay Brewster at jay.brewster@pepperdine.edu).  This REU site is co-funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences), and the Division of Mathematical Sciences (Directorate for Mathematical & Physical Sciences).

por.por_cntn:
The Pepperdine Summer Undergraduate Research in Biology (SURB) program is an NSF-funded program that offers summer research fellowships to undergraduate students. The program supports 8 students each summer, providing each student a full-time, 11-week research experience. Students are closely mentored by Pepperdine faculty; provided a generous student stipend, free housing on campus at Pepperdine, and support for travel to research conference following program completion. The central goal of the SURB program is to encourage the development of young scientists via engagement of undergraduates in research; partnering students with faculty mentors in the development of a novel research project. Research students engage the theme of stress adaptation of biological systems. Projects within the program include ecology, cell biology, plant physiology, mathematical modeling of biological systems, and biochemistry. Students are welcomed into the scientific community, enjoying opportunities for social engagement, service, and the hosting of guest scientists from around the world. 

 

The key objectives of the program are to:

1)     enhance the maturation of undergraduate students as young scientists via direct faculty mentoring within the context of an active research laboratory;

2)     engage students in full-time biological research by experimentally testing student-generated hypotheses, resulting in publishable data sets that are communicated effectively;

3)     teach students the essentials of the scientific process which are common to a spectrum of biological sub-disciplines;

4)     introduce students to collaboration and interdisciplinary research;

5)     and provide research opportunities for students from traditionally under-represented groups or students from schools that lack research opportunities.

 

 Students that have participated in the SURB program over the past 5 years of this current grant have been successful in addressing important publishable questions in biology, have engaged the broader scientific community effectively, and have been a diverse group of talented students from across the United States. SURB students funded through this grant have authored 23 research articles in respected, peer-reviewed scientific journals. The publication of research results generated during the SURB program in truly challenging due to the brevity of the program and the rigor required of such scholarly communications.  These publications attest to the quality of the research projects being performed, the quality of the students participating in the program, and the extended connection between SURB students and their faculty mentor during the process of publishing in a peer-reviewed journal. In addition, SURB students funded by this grant have made over 133 conference presentations as they communicate their research findings to the scientific community. Examples include the Ecological Society of America and the American Society for Cell Biology, which offer important opportunities for undergraduate students to network and to prepare for graduate school application. Of the students funded in this grant, 67% have subsequently entered or plan to enter into graduate level training or careers in the research biosciences. The SURB alumni are succeeding in gaining access to graduate programs and will become important members of the U.S. STEM professionals. When requesting funds for this grant, we set a goal of enriching the SURB program with a more diverse collection of students. Of the students funded with this grant, 61% were from groups that are underrepresented in science. Since 2015, SURB students have come from 23 different colleges and universities, distributed among 20 states. Of those students, 75% have come from institutions that lack a Ph.D. in STEM disciplines.

 

With regard to tracking SURB alumni, we have maintained a database of contact information and of career outcomes.  Alumni are invited to keep in touch with the SURB program through regular emails, and through announcements and program photographs posted to the SURB website.  Administrative staff and faculty mentors work to keep in contact with SURB alumni to keep abreast of developments in their careers.
